instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - cremated <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
threads.message:
I've just had one of the above in.  bits of stray metal wire all over the motherboard (abortive hookup wires?) and many of the probe points are bright blue; some are purplish.  It looks like a huge current has passed through the board.

no orange light, no green light no PPBUS.  

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets very hot.  When I removed it, many of the pads came with it (pin 9,10,11 and 15 - some others are dodgy too).  

but even with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> removed there is still very low resistance on the pp1v05 circuit and the pp1v2 circuit

no evident liquid damage on the board itself.  one component show arcing (<RESISTOR>R1270</RESISTOR>).  the backlight fuse has gone and <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> looked like all the balls on the edge side had fused.

the IO board does have signs of liquid damage but the components look ok if skanky; and it is sending the 15+V to the logic board.

this feels like it's going to be beyond profitable repair.  hooking up <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is feasible (ish) but my concern is that with the liquid damage on the IO board and the arcing on the 1v+ lines, there could be much more that is dead.

Anyone seen anything similar?  Feelings on being worth repair?

thanks
Justin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - cremated <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
threads.message: Board will work on a charged battery without <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> installed to see if there is any life. It sounds pretty bad though and probably a RIP.
